Brooklyn Collection
Bob Gore photograph collection
Gore, Bob
BCMS.0049
12.12 Gigabytes in 148 digital photographic images in tiff format.
2007-2020 Digital photographs by Bob Gore showing various events in Brooklyn including a Lowa wedding ceremony, the West Indian American Day Carnival Parade, the Tribute to the Ancestors ceremony, the Gateway to Nations powwow, and the Black Lives Matter protests. This collection is available digitally here.
Arrangement
Photographs are labled according to the library's standard cataloging procedures and ordered by accession date.
Biographical
Bob Gore is a New York based photographer and film producer whose work documents worship traditions in the United States and the Caribbean. He is the official photographer of the Abyssinan Baptist Church and author of We've Come This Far: Abyssinian Baptist Church and Good News from Haiti: The Work of Bethlehem Ministry. His work has appeared numerous exhibits and publications.
Access
This collection is available digitally through the library's digital collections portal.
Use
While many items in the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
Preferred Citation
Bob Gore photograph collection, date, item number, Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.
Immediate Source of Aquisition
This collection was purchased from Bob Gore.
Scope and Contents
The Bob Gore collection consists of digital photographs taken at five Brooklyn events: a Lowa wedding ceremony in Flatbush, circa 2007; the Tribute to the Ancestors ceremony at Coney Island, memorializing enslaved Africans who died at sea in their forced passage to the Americas, 2008; the Gateway to Nations powwow at Floyd Bennett Field in June, 2010; the West Indian American Day Carnival Parade in 2017; and the Black Lives Matter protests, 2020.
